w:r.w:t: A React component undergoes three phases in its lifecycle: mounting, updating, and unmounting.
is when a new component is created and inserted into the DOM or, in other words, when the life of a component begins. This can only happen once, and is often called “initial render.”
is when the component updates or re-renders. This
reaction is triggered when the props are updated or when the state is updated. This phase can occur multiple times, which is kind of the point of React.
The last phase within a component's lifecycle is the
, when the component is removed from the DOM.

In a class-based component, you can call different methods for each phase of the lifecycle (more on this below). These lifecycle methods are of course not applicable to functional components because they can
only be written/contained within a class. However,
hooks give functional components the ability to use states.
Hooks have gaining popularity because they make working with React cleaner and often less verbose.
learn more about the methods that make up each of our three phases.
In the mounting phase, a component is prepared for and actually inserted into the DOM. To
get through this phase, four lifecycle methods are called: constr
The constructor method is the very first method called during the mounting phase.
It's important to remember that you shouldn't add any side effects within this method (like sending an HTTP request) as it's intended to be pure.
This method is mostly used for initializing the state of the component and binding
hin the component. The constructor method is not necessarily required. If you don't intend to make your component
(or if that state doesn’t need to be initialized) or bind any method, then it’s not necessary to implement.

is called when the component is initiated, but before it’s rendered. It’s also called with props as an argument. It's important you call the super(props) function with the props argument passed onto it within the constructor before any other steps are tak
This will then initiate the constructor of
(the parent of this class-based component) and it inherits the constructor method and other methods of a typical React component.
In the Counter component, you can see the component's sta
constructor method to keep track of the count state. The
attached to your button in this case, is bound within the constructor.
s and state are completely different concepts, and part of building your app intelligently is deciding which data goes where.
In many cases though, your component’s state will be
of its props. This is where the static

method comes in. This method allows you to modify the state value with any props value. It's most useful for changes in props over time, and we’ll learn later that it’s also useful in the update phase.

two arguments: props and state, and returns an object, or null if no change is needed. These values are passed directly to the method, so there’s no need for it to have access to the instance of the class (or any other part of the class) and thus is consi
method is called after the constructor method and right before the component is rendered. This is the most rarely used method in this phase, but it’s still important to know so y
ou can use it if needed.
Another way of looking at it is just providing a default for your component state based on props.
The render method is the only required method for a class-based React component. It’s called after the
method and actually renders or inserts the HTML to the DOM.
Typically, the render method returns the JSX which will eventually be rendered, but it can also return other values.
It's important to remember that the render method

is meant to be pure. This means you can’t modify the state, have any direct interaction with the browser, or any other kind of side effect like sending an HTTP request. Just think of it as writing HTML, but of course as JSX.
is the last lifecycle method called in the mounting phase. It’s called right after the component is rendered or mounted to the DOM.
With this method, you're allowed to add side effects like sending network requests or updating the component's state. Additionally, the
method allows you to make subscriptions like subscribing to the
store. You can also call the
method right away; however this will cause a re-render as it kicks in the update phase, since the state has changed.
You need to be careful with
A common use case is waiting unt
il a component renders to start an animation, or fetching data from an external source.
The Updating phase is triggered when component props or state change, and consists of the following methods: static
and render are also part of the mounting phase. Since they’ve been covered previously, this section focuses on the other three methods.
In the update phase, the first lifecycle method called is
. This method is useful if you have updated props and you want to reflect that in the component's state.
te may depend on the value of its props.
, before the component was even re-rendered, its state can reflect those changes and can be shown (if applicable) to the newly updated component.
Remember, this method is rarely us
ed and isn’t ideal for most situations.
is another rarely used lifecycle method. It’s specifically intended for
performance optimization, and basically lets you tell React when you
when a new state or props comes in. While it can help avoid re-renders, you shouldn’t rely on it to
re-renders since you might skip a necessary update and encounter bugs.
To prevent renders, you can opt in to logical rendering inste

as arguments, however, they’re optional, and you can declare it without the arguments. This method then returns a Boolean value. The Boolean value defines whether a re-render happens. The default value is true
happens in all cases whenever state or props changes.

gives you access to the previous props and state of the component before it's updated. This allows you to work or check on the previous values of the state or props. It’s another method that’s rarely used.
A good use case for this method is handling sc
roll positions in a chat app. When a new message comes in as the user is viewing old messages, it shouldn’t push the old ones out of view.
is called after the render method, and before
method returns anything, it will be passed as a parameter for the

ide effects like sending network requests or calling the
method. It’s important to remember that there should always be a way to avoid the
(like some sort of logic), or it will result in an infinite loop of re-rendering.

The unmounting phase is the third and final phase of a React component. At this phase, the component is
removed from the DOM. Unmounting only has one lifecycle method involved:
is invoked right before the component is unmounted or removed from the DOM. It’s meant for any necessary
of the component, like unsubscribing to any subscriptions (i.e.,
) or canceling any network requests. Once this method is done executing
REACT HOOKS AND THE COMPONENT LIFECYCLE
Versions of React before 16.8 consider two kinds of components based on
component, and the stateless functional components (often refer

red to as a “dumb component”). But with the release of React 16.8, Hooks were introduced and empowered developers to access state from functional components, instead of writing an entire class. With this change, building components became easier and less v
Hooks known as default hooks come with React, and you’re also able to create your own custom hook. A custom hook is just a function that starts with use, like
The two most common default hooks are
hook gives state to the functional component, and
allows you to add side effects within it (like after initial render), which aren’t allowed within the function's main body. You can also act upon updates on the state with
React has released more default hooks, but
are the ones you should be most familiar with. Let’s take a look at how they work and compare them to the component lifecycle we covered above.
to store state for a functional component. This hook accepts one parameter:

Hooks popularized their use among developers who prefer using functional components rather than traditional,
But what if your class-based component’s state object has plenty of items like this:
You might be tempted at first to use on
hook, and build some sort of dictionary to hold all of this state. But React allows you to have multiple
functional component. So instead of one single object, you can set each item of the state object into its own state:
With a lot of different “types” of state this can obviously get verbose, so exercise judgment for larger components.
) method of a class-based component, the main body of a functional component should be kept pure. With
, you're able to create side effects while maintaining the component's purity. Within this hook, you can send network requests, make subscriptions, and change the state value.

hook accepts a function as an argument, where you write all your side effects. This function is invoked after every browser paint and before any new renders (this will depend on the dependency array, which is explained in the next paragraph). This functio

n can return another function called the clean-up function, which can be used to clean up the side effects (i.e. when the component is destroyed) like unsubscribing to a store. It’s kind of a mash up of several of the methods explained in the previous sect
This Hook accepts a second argument called the dependency array, which is an array of dependencies like state or props values, which the
uses as reference to only run when these values change. If the dependency array is empty, then the
will only run once, after the first paint.
The dependency array is optional, so if it's not defined,
will fire first when the component is first mounted, and then on every re-render.
will only run once, since the dependency array is empty. Within the input function, the subscription to the
store is invoked, which returns an unsubscribe function. This unsubscribe function is returned, which serves as the clean-up function.

nce it’s invoked on every state/props change. The difference is that you can specifically choose
